Here’s a more accurate fact about red dwarfs?
Not all red dwarf stars will survive their trillion year life time,
Some or most red dwarfs will be annihilated by ether other red dwarfs or by other violent(and even gruesome) events, such as supernovae, gamma ray bursts, other stars, and dead stars(even white dwarf stars can destroy red dwarfs without exploding in a supernova), and other stuff.
And the most common violent event is when red dwarfs collide with other red dwarfs,
and these two semi ordinary stars collide and merge with each other, they create a explosion called a brown nova or red dwarf merger,
And this collision of the the most common stars in the universe, is very amazingly and unique,
and these not so powerful collisions are so common that they can even collide in double twin pairs(or even more twin pairs),
And almost no other star type can do this multiple colliding event, especially dead stars(black holes are the other exception I can think of),
And when these multiple binary pairs collide they can recreate a Emission Nebula( a type of space cloud),
And when these remnant clouds collide it could possibly make new stars(but this event will mostly produce brown dwarfs, since red dwarfs are less than 50% the mass of the sun, in other words when these gas clouds from the red dwarf mergers collide, it will only be able to brown dwarfs, and a occasionally few red dwarfs),
And brown dwarf collisions are what creates red dwarfs, rather than typical star formation, in other words it can take a long time for red dwarf stars to form?!

For anyone who didn’t understand the convective part:
Stars fuse hydrogen in their cores. More massive stars only fuse hydrogen in their cores, so only the core hydrogen can be available for fusion, even though there is many hydrogen in the outer layer that can’t be fused unless it reaches the core. Red dwarfs, however, are able to mix the gas, bringing in fresh hydrogen from the outer layer to the core so it can be used for fusion. That way, they don’t waste so much fuel and so they are able the last longer. They also burn slower, making their fuel last even longer.

There is just as much of a chance of life surviving around white dwarfs as the red variety and that could sustain life a long time too. Even when red dwarfs die, new ones are being created so do not think life will end in 10-15 trillion years. Gravity will pull in more gas, exploding stars will generate still more and as we drift thru space, the possibilities are endless. Who's to say that long after earth is a dead world, our solar system won't drift thru a hydrogen cloud somewhere in our 's or another galaxy's area and have enough gas drawn into Jupiter for it to become a red dwarf? Besides, most likely, having a star is not required for life to survive. What about the moons revolving around our solar system with liquid ocean's beneath them? Many of these have liquid oceans not because of its location in relation to our sun but because of the tidal pressures from gravity from their larger planets. And...if they have the right kind of atmosphere, it could probably retain enough heat to not even freeze the surface. Personally, even including the expansion or the theory of the big freeze that some think await us eventually, I do not see the end coming. Look how we have evolved in just over the last few thousand years: Earth is a little more than 4 billion years old and yet the universe is a little less than 14 billion years of age. Thats almost a 10 billion year difference. Given that we are average in our universe, that means the first civilization was probably started about 6 billion years before us, give or take. Imagine what we might develop if we survive another 4 billion years. I have no doubt we could manipulate matter and gravity by then...perhaps converting dark matter to matter and creating our own hydrogen. For all we know, that is exactly why we exist: Some smart alien seeded our solar system to make a soft spot for life to land.

I had a crazy idea.

If cryogenic sleep ever becomes a thing (as well as being able to create wormholes), we could place one end of a wormhole on a ship with cryogenic sleep pods inside of it. We would then send it, as well as many other similar ships to the Earth-like planets that orbit around red dwarfs in the habitable zone. Since the journey will be at least 4.3 light-years (that’s the distance to the closest star that isn’t our sun, Proxima Centauri) the journey would take thousands of years. So, the pilot/pilots would be placed in cryogenic sleep for 99.99% of the journey, giving them time to prepare a safe landing on the surface once they get close. Once they land, they’d place the wormhole on the surface.
This would enable people on Earth to travel to the other planets instantly.
Then we just rinse and repeat this cycle for other places in the galaxy!

Also for an interstellar civilisation I don't know why they would be particularly concerned about living on a planet, as they will have spent 100's - 10,000's of years living in rotating habitats to get there, and if you are living in a rotating habitat for short duration solar flares they could just absorb the heat into the outer layer which would presumably just be rock left over from getting out the metals to make the inner drum, which rock isn't known for it's great thermal conductivity. Longer term you would have at least 2 drums inside such a structure spinning in opposite directions so the rotation does not create toque which could flip the drum.
-
So you could just turn the hole structure so it had less area was revealed to the sun, or have gaint cooling fins facing away from the star, secondly if you REALLY wanted to live on a planet you could just reflect light down with mirrors onto the dark side of the planet, again you are arriving from space and the last thing you would do is colonise the planet, you would set up your space infrastructure first like orbital rings, mass drivers, asteroid mining facilities etc. So making a giant mirror that can dynamically change it's reflectivity based on the stars output isn't actually as big of a job a you might think it was. All you would need to do is make it out of a lot of smaller mirrors which can rotate quickly.
-
Although in ~10k years I don't know why you are not starting just stripping stars down for their mass and throwing that into kugelblitz black holes to get your energy rather than relying on stars which only tun 5% of rest mass into energy, instead you can get 100%, and if you want something that is Star like just using a few kugelblitz black holes to heat up a shell which can re-emit the energy in the wavelength you want... as black holes give off x-rays to gamma rays, so you don't want to use the "light" directly.
-
but that means you are not losing mass to solar wind, although you would need to create a solar system covering magnetic field to protect you from interstellar radiation, but you could just have a giant lump of iron in the middle of you artificial star which as long as you didn't apply the heat evenly would convect and create a magnetic field, which would trap charges particles.
-
Although you may just leave a red dwarfs going just to turn Hydrogen into Tritium, Deuterium and He3 so then you can fuse them into heavier elements until you can't get any more energy out, at which point you would use a gaint particle accelerator to create even heavier elements. Because fusing protium is a pain in the ass and you would almost certainly leave that to stars if you wanted to make heavier elements or if you want energy, just throw it into a kugelblitz black hole.

Na, I don't think Red Dwarfs will be our final solution, as even a black dwarf has a stupid amount of mass, which if you have kugelblitz black holes you can turn that mass into energy with 100% efficiency, even if you just use a regular black hole you can just throw the mass from the white dwarf into it and gain energy from it falling in, which I believe is about 60% efficient.

Rather biased toward planets. Planets may be the least useful place to settle.

Planets are big gravity wells. As such they're hard to land on and difficult to take off from again. The easiest planets to land on are those with thick atmospheres, even easier if they have large bodies of liquid water. But a thick atmosphere and liquid surface make them the hardest to take off from. No atmosphere means having to use propulsion all the way to the surface, but easiest to take off from with electromagnetic mass driver.

Rotating planets come with inconvenient day/night cycles. The really slow ones will have long days but challenging nights. The faster the spin the better with the shortest night to tough out.

Tidally locked planets will have the least inhabitable surface.

By far the superior choice will be free-floating spinning habitats. A meagre gravity well that's very easy to arrive and depart. No day/night cycle.

Build spinning habitats within a non-spinning shell. Shell should be layered with moderately consolidated collision shield of rocks and metals and a water jacket a few metres thick for radiation shielding.

No need to wait on a planet within a star's habitable zone, we can place habitats in the habitable zone. But habitats are not restricted to the habitable zone and need only extra heat rejection or heat gathering structures to wander well outside the star's habitable zone.

All we really need is a star system with some leftover debris around it to gather and mould into habitats. To make our efforts worthwhile we'll want to choose long-lived stars that aren't too close to big and dangerous other stellar objects.

The size and color of a star are indicative of the temperature of the stars core where science is suggesting that a stars kinetic energy is a function of a fixed amount of mass, this is erroneous thinking and has dwarfed are perceptions of cosmology.  Jupiter is a star in the form of liquid hydrogen, it has the same mass as our star but its kinetic energy is at an all time low due to its proximity of our sun.  As our star ages it will grow in size and the habitable zone will reach beyond the asteroid belt influencing the temperature of Jupiter so as to turn a LIQUID GAS GIANT INTO A GAS GIANT AND THIS IS WHERE THE GAS COLAPSES TO FORM A STAR, STARS ARE NOT FORMED FROM ROGUE GASES OF HYDROGEN BUT RATHER SOLID AND LIQUID GAS GIANTS SUCH AS NEPTUNE URANUS SATURN AND JUPITER. Red dwarf stars as a "new home for humanity" or "the last home of humanity", or talk of "civilization for trillions of years", as "we have plenty of time before the universe turns out the lights"...

It's always amusing to me that anyone considers human life beyond a few thousand years from now. We have only yet existed as modern humans for only a few thousand years (200Ky anatomically, but likely <70Ky intellectually). After much less than one million years, humanity will have evolved and changed into species that would no longer be considered homo sapiens sapiens – the you and me beings as we are now all over the world. After millions of years, any descendants of humans would be unrecognizable as humans. And, that is IF we survive that long. Natural extinction-level mega-catastrophes are bound to happen by then, and – even more likely – our own man-made planet-wide disasters are likely to throw us back into a stone-age existence much sooner, like within hundreds or thousands of years.* To talk about what humanity will do when the sun extinguishes in billions of years is preposterous! Discussions of what we can do when the universe approaches heat death in trillions of years... well, that is just an unfathomable time span, indistinguishable from eternity to us humans. Let's face it – it is not just your life that is but a mere instant of cosmic time, but the entire existence of the human race is much less than a blink in the cosmos.

* Don't count on humans persisting by finding safe harbor within other worlds. Though we are on track to sending humans to other planets and moons within our solar system, since faster-than-light travel is not physically possible, we are not likely to colonize beyond our own solar system. Human colonies and outposts outside of Earth will require the most sophisticated technology for life support, making them way more fragile than life on Earth, since any critical failure will spell doom. Reaching another star system would be a voyage of multiple generations, during which the pioneers would be highly vulnerable and helpless. Plus we can't be certain that the target destination is hospitable enough, nor would it be feasible to change destinations mid-course. Then there's the limitation that terraforming another planet would take dozens if not hundreds of human lifespans, and even by then the target planet would not be as livable as the Earth we have evolved within. Sorry – I'd love to be more optimistic, but these are the realities.

I seem to recall one of the Star Wars books (yeah, great source of scientific info there) having a planet that was tidally locked but had an intelligent species living on the narrow temperate band in constant twilight. Their form of execution was exile to the hot side of the planet.

I'm not sure if there was any indiginous life in this book, or if it was meant to be a colony of some kind. I seem to recall the descriptions largely being of barren rock outside the settlements, which suggests a colony that brought their ecosystem with them.

I take this with a hefty degree of skeptecism, though. Keep in mind this is a universe that has either had a planetbusting weapon shoot several planets simultaneously and had those shots visible from several others, or one where The Crystal Star is a thing that happened, depending on if you want the new canon or the old. (The physics breaking planetbuster isn't even extended universe, that's the bloody movie I'm talking about. At least Crystal Star can be chalked up to poor management of third party contributions to the canon.)

Could there be multiple universes? If we live as far as the year 1 trillion, our tech may be so advanced that we may travel about the same speed as light. If one universe dies, another one is created. What we are saying is based off the observable universe, so there could be more universes beyond that of which is habitable. And if that doesn't work, scientists have to figure out how to travel through a black hole. There are so many things in the universe we don't even know, so we can't just come to the conclusion that eventually we will no longer exist because all of the stars in the universe will die. We still need to figure out if there are multiple universes,how black holes work, and how to improve our technology so that life is sustainable. Who knows, we might become SO advanced that we can create a barrier around the sun to prevent it from dying, or even creating an ARTIFICIAL sun. Nothing is impossible, we just need to find out a way of how to make it possible.

We may not even ever need to leave Earth. Through a procedure called "Starlifting" we may one day extract hydrogen and helium from the Sun, which (when done in large quantities) would cause it to dim a bit and live much longer. Do it enough and Sun may even revert to a red dwarf, but that would take so much starlifting that with the fuel we got from it, we may power billions of fusion reactors.
Certain people are of the opinion that we need only reduce the Suns mass enough to double its current lifespan and build a Dyson swarm around it to get all the energy we could ever concievably need.

Ideas.
The universe could be like a human. For about 10 hours (10s of trillions of years), you're active (day). Then, as you may go to bed, the stars in the universe could fade out (getting tired). When the last star or celestial object dies out, it could be lasting for a period of time (aka nighttime, asleep), only to reform again trillions of years later (awake in the morning)? It could be reforming as in eventually, gas and matter would get together, and the universe could be "reborn". If living beings could find a way to sustain themselves over the trillions of years, or guide the reformation of the universe along, speeding it up... many new possibilities could open up. This is highly unlikely, but the thought just came to me.

It's hilarious that people find this sort of thing depressing. Such people have absolutely no sense of scale. These incomprehensibly vast time frames have no meaning for humanity. Even before the Earth becomes uninhabitable, nothing remotely resembling humans will exist anymore. Earth will become uninhabitable in about one billion years. It's only been about half that long since the first marine animals appeared in the ocean. Anatomically modern humans have only been around for around two-hundred thousand years, or one five-thousandth of the billion years that life has left on the planet. Are you starting to get the picture? There are so many perfectly good reasons to get depressed in life, but this isn't one of them. (Although I suppose anyone who adheres to the ludicrous hope that humans will somehow last "forever" [whatever that means exactly] will find this just as disheartening. Whatevah.)

I was never a fan of Carter Catastrophe reasoning, but this video has made me a convert. If Red Dwarves were truly potential incubators of life, then the chances of our own evolution in the necessary 5bn years of the life cycle of a G class star would be utterly minuscule, compared with having been born orbiting one of the 70%+ majority of stars, at any point in a 100 trillion year window. Which implies that not only are Red Dwarves clearly not suitable incubators of intelligent life, but realistically, we are IT. We are all there is, at least in this galaxy. And we're near the end, too, and we ain't going anywhere else to live, or expand into the Universe.

So, if the stars die, and the universe goes dark, what's the point? What's the point of trying to go as far as we can into space and trying to get as advanced as we can? Why are we trying to find out what existence is? If it's all going to be erased then why write it in the first place?

"uplifting" really? Even if humans (or whatever we become) exist that long that is not a comforting thought. Basically the laws of physics are a death sentence that nothing can escape. Stars die, matter itself comes apart at the seams, and black holes evaporate. At some point the universe will be dead, kaput, nothing but low energy photons that have little chance of interacting with anything, ever. The universe is not eternal. even the most massive objects, black holes with billions of times the mass of our sun evaporate over time (10^92 - 10^93 years). After that there is nothing, no energy produced and thus no life. Without life, time has no meaning. the universe will span on to infinity with no change and nothing happening. It will be dead, done, with nothing. Existentially distressing I know, but do not despair. The sooner we unite as a species, the sooner we understand it all. Who knows, maybe then we will find a way to preserve our race past the end of our universe by moving to another. After many years of university I have learned at lest one thing: everything is possible in physics, water may even fall up. We humans need a similar miracle, but who knows what the future may bring.

1:49 You spelled "analyzing" wrong. Not to be a grammar Nazi or anything. I love your videos! :-)

See by Freeman Dyson "Time without End: Physics and Biology in an open universe"

If I remember correctly he cites a estimate that's most often accepted for time left until protons decay 10^10^76 years. If things keep expanding as they are <i>even without actually accelerating</i> the sky could go dark to our best instruments.
After that we'd better have either found a way to live without wavicles. Maybe some could send info to make ourselves at the first instant after Planck's time at the formation of the universe. Or else escape the limits of space/time. We do know time-travel isn't impossible, it's a good bet that tailor-making a tesseract isn't out of the question. It's kind of the same thing, right?

We should suspect that as we learn more about the nature of space/time and matter/energy, we'll learn about warping space. If you can make a door across the galaxy for a person or a space ship, making extra-dimensionality our normal state, isn't too far out.
It might seem suspicious that for all the positive chances for life, nobody yet in a billion years or more, seems to have expanded across space. Either life doesn't make it off-planet to space-faring or our ideas about interstellar colonization, civilization, and/or empire, are in need of revision.

How about this, a planet with earth-like properties orbiting a Jupiter-like planet, that spinning around the red dwarf sun... Even if the earth is tidally locked around Jupiter, so to speak, it would still alternate facing its sun, with the Jupiter like planet also acting as a shield, of sorts, for solar flares, if colonists lived on the side facing the parent planet. Tidal forces would also (one hopes) keep the Earth-like moon's core liquid so we always have a magnetic field to protect from atmosphere loss, though my understanding is that red dwarfs have less of a solar wind issue in any case. To me, it seems like this would have a lot of potential as an 'ideal' colonist setting, if longevity is our concern (a sun that won't get too hot as ours will in a billion years, or, if fossil fuel burning continues at its present levels unchecked, a few hundred).

Considering the size of red dwarfs, it'd probably be a lot easier to build a Dyson sphere around one. In terms of expended resources, at least.

Also, considering the potential instability of red dwarfs with the super sunspots, vicious solar flares, and potential tidal locking, colonies on those planets would probably be either contained complexes or underground habitats. Hell, at any moment one of those worlds could be reduced to a dirty snowball, where it's cold outside and there's no kind of atmosphere. Maybe, in the galaxy, we're all alone. More or less.

Out-of-the-box scenario:
If humanity could survive another million years, or for any technologically advanced civilization, it will probably:
* master nuclear fusion and harvest hydrogen from brown dwarves
* split red dwarves into brown dwarves to stop nuclear fusion and make them as colossal hydrogen reservoirs in space for later usage (cf below)
* when our sun (or their sun) burns out its fuel and changes into red giant, and our Earth becomes inhabitable:
- we will pull many red dwarves and brown dwarves together to form a new star and ignite nuclear fusion and voilà! A new sun!
- we will either choose an existing planet in the habitable zone or just pull one into orbit of habitable zone. No more "tidally lock and all kinds of problems" as stated in the video.
- Of course, with the master of nuclear fusion reaching that ultra technological level, humanity probably does not need a sun in the sky at all! But hey! Who knows, maybe they will still be nostalgic and need a Sun to shine in the sky to make them feel comfortable! ;-)

The idea that there'll be 'humanity' 1 billion years from now is quite a long shot. 1 billion years ago, only bacterial life existed on earth. Since then, the full spectrum of life evolved, died out, evolved, and so on. Even assuming humans don't nuke our selves out of existence, die in a freak cosmic accident, or simply starve due to changing terrestrial conditions - it's a safe bet that our descendents will change drastically over the course of 1 billion years. As always, Astronomy is full of dogma and slow to change. For those that want a crystal ball of future discoveries possibly beyond your lifetime, stars are not made of hydrogen. No star observed to date has the needed mass for hydrogen. No circulation occurs or has ever been observed even when directly observed. Nearly everything about stars fails rudimentary observations. Stars do have cores but they are not fusion cores, they are fission cores and are not that hot. The core is wrapped with plasma with a surface on par with red dwarfs. The brighter outer layers are above the surface of the star and is where fusion occurs. On our star it is 4500 kilometers above the surface. Being made of plasma, stars are heavily influenced by the behavior of their magnetic fields.
But don't earth-like planets lose their magnetic field (and thus their atmosphere) before the sun expands?

I would say it's too much of an oversight to define 'habitable' as able to support liquid water. Just because water is our life liquid doesn't mean the same for other worlds, for example if a planet or moon had liquid methane, ethane, butane or some other hydrocarbon on its surface some form of cryogenic life could arise. It may even be possible for a life from to use liquid oxygen
But I always thought Red Dwarfs would be the best for long-term life, providing that life with incredibly long amounts of time to advance and develop technology fro traversing the universe, though I think Red Dwarf life will be mostly cryogenic or near cryogenic life which would allow the planets to be further from the star.
And for water based life around Red Dwarfs, the oceans might have high salt content or ammonia in them, lowering the freezing point of them and allowing the planet to be further out. Just some thoughts. Great video.

Just want to remind you guys that all of this "concrete" information - like the part where Red Dwarfs last over 10 trillion years - have been decided over information gained by long range imaging over the past few decades.

We don't actually KNOW how a Red Dwarf works on the inside - not really.
Just like how we don't know what's going on beneath the skin of our own sun, not really. Sure we can take a guess, but we don't really have much to go on anyway.

A few guys looked at different images of Red Dwarfs and then said "These things probably last 10 trillion years based off of our crude imaging.
We really know nothing about them, people should probably stop blowing up all of the speculation that has very little actual scientific evidence to back it up.

(Translation from Swedish)

"Since we still don't have a clue about what dark energy really is, I would distribute the odds /of what way the universe will die in/ the following way:

40% for Big Chill /The one suggested in the video/
9% for Big Chrunch
1% for Big Rip

"But the remaining 50% then? I reserve them for the option "none of the above", because I think we humans have to be humble and admit that there still are completely fundamental things we do not understand, among others the nature of the universe.

I haven't been subscribed for long but in just the last two or three videos that I've watched, I've found multiple statements of fact made that are - at best - unconfirmed; and at worst, purely the author's opinion and belief.

I stopped watching this video three sentences in and started writing this comment immediately because within those three sentences 'In a Nutshell' had already stated without an "if" or a "may" or a "possible," that the universe WILL END in entropic heat death; as though "It's just a given... Moving on now. If you don't accept it, you won't get the next part." The way that 'In a Nutshell' is communicating science is the same way that religion has gone about spreading spiritual belief systems since the dark ages: Say what YOU believe with total conviction, drop the mic, and walk out. It reminds me very much of the last time someone asked me if I'd accepted Jesus Christ as my personal savior.

It's okay if that's what you believe. If you comfort yourself in the darkness of night with the warm cuddly blanket of nihilism, that's fine. But when you stand up and claim the role of educator, and then you sell your personal beliefs as scientific fact, without a caveat or a "maybe," or the hint of a suggestion that there are other possibilities... You do a disservice to the role you took, and to every person who comes to you seeking answers.

It's not an unfair or glaringly wrong conclusion to extrapolate the laws of thermodynamics and the measured expansion of the universe to imply that heat-death is where its all heading, but given the extreme brevity of humanity's observations of the universe, as well as -- ya' know: the fact that anything exists in the first place... There's more than a few wrenches lodged in that particular hypothesis.

Maybe you don't realize that young minds are coming here to learn, and that some of those minds are willing to absorb anything you give them as long as you give it with absoluteness. The matter-of-fact way that this channel has, many times implied or outright stated that "things are like this and there is no competing theory," influences minds. I've seen it in your comment section; Seen young people asking, "Is this really true?!" and commenting "Wow, it's bleak to think that..." about things you present as absolutes that the scientific community knows are very much in question, require further study, and are up for debate.

These videos and this channel's statements are not irrefutably right. The many alternate possibilities you ignore are equally, not irrefutably right. They are merely the known possibilities. And it is the responsibility of anyone who climbs up the soapbox to act as educator - especially in the name of science - to make clear the difference between opinion and hypothesis; hypothesis and theory; theory and fact. This channel too often skips the middle two and presents the author's opinion as absolute truth.

Please review your practices. And stop telling people that the universe ends in infinite expansion and cessation of energetic interaction. Noting that the ripples on the pond all eventually still is good. Failing to address the source of the ripples, or to recognize that no stillness has ever been maintained, is not.

Every scientist always talks in ultimatums, "this will happen," for example, our sun will burn out in about a billion years. This leaves a lot of people to think that humanity will not survive for much longer. Yet, everyone forgets that just over a hundred years ago, humankind thought flight was impossible, in fact the New York Times predicted it would be 10 million years before we became advanced enough to fly. That very same year, the Wright Brothers flew at Kittyhawk. Since then we have advanced exponentially as a species.
NASA predicts that interstellar travel will become possible in around 200 years. A billion years is a long time, friends. We just have to hold on.
Besides, the biggest thing that could cause our extinction in the near future is ourselves.

Does it not makes sense that life is somewhat more than molecules reacting and slowly releasing energy until death? I mean possibly in the scientific sense too... Life is extropy, life is what balances the universe's entropy, and I think this will soon begin to be theorized as we delve deeper into quantum science, the mind-boggling science of sub-atomic and elementary particles and their relation to wave energy, it may be the pinnacle that explains many of our yet unsolved mysteries! :)
